Experience PhD student/Stanford Graduate Fellow Stanford University September 2009  – Present (6 years) * PhD student with Mark Schnitzer (Applied Physics, Biology, Neuroscience, Howard Hughes). 
* Collaborated with Pfizer to create a new preclinical screening platform for Parkinson’s and discover important biological mechanisms driving the disease. 
* Built pipelines (MATLAB) to analyze massive (>50 TB) datasets with advanced machine learning and statistical tools.  
* Invented new optical technology for recording neural activity. 1 pending patent. 
* 3 papers published in Nature Neuroscience, Nature Methods, ACS Nano, 3 manuscripts in preparation. Presented work at 5 meetings in the U.S. and Asia. Co-author on 10 conference posters. Summary I'm currently part of the leadership recruiting team at Facebook, providing executive search services to our engineering teams. 
 
For the last 4 years, I specialized in identifying engineering and design elite for Silicon Valley startups. 
 
I excel at building profitable relationships, from small local businesses to large, multi-national corporations. I bring a strong track record of sales and business development within the retail, organic foods, and innovation industries. Prior to that, I worked as an environmental engineering consultant for a project management firm. Summary Robert Munro is a computational linguist and data scientist working at the leading edge of scalable language technologies. He is a world leader in applying machine learning, natural language processing, crowdsourcing and big data analytics to human communication. He has worked in many diverse environments, from Sierra Leone, Haiti and the Amazon to London, Sydney and San Francisco, with organizations ranging from Silicon Valley Startups to the United Nations. 
 
Robert has published more than 50 papers on natural language processing and is a regular speaker about technology in an increasingly connected world. He has a PhD from Stanford University. Experience Chief Executive Officer Idibon January 2012  – Present (3 years 8 months) San Francisco Bay Area I founded Idibon and drive our vision, decisions and strategic direction. I have brought together one of the strongest teams in natural language processing, helping the leading global organizations understand their language and communication data. It is a pleasure leading our team towards the shared vision of bringing language technologies to all the world's languages. Chief Information Officer Energy For Opportunity July 2009  –  December 2012  (3 years 6 months) I managed the information and communication systems for our West African-based Solar Power operations, helping the company from its launch to see it grow to become the leading renewable energy provider in the region. This built on work prior to moving to the US when I lived in Sierra Leone, working for the Environmental Foundation for Africa, and for the UN High Commission for Refugees in Liberia. I still serve on the board of EFO. Graduate Fellow Stanford University September 2007  –  June 2012  (4 years 10 months) I researched machine-learning and natural language processing systems to support scalable information processing, especially in the context of low-resourced languages and noisy data. CTO EpidemicIQ, Global Viral Forecasting January 2011  –  December 2011  (1 year) San Francisco I lead the design and implementation of the core information and prediction engine to track all the world's disease outbreaks and potential pandemics, pulling in all available digital data from millions of sources in dozens of languages. Coordinator Mission 4636 January 2010  –  May 2010  (5 months) I coordinated the translation, geolocation and categorization of emergency text messages sent in Haiti in the wake of January 12, 2010 earthquake. This was the first step in the only emergency response service available to people within Haiti during this critical period.  
 
Working with about 2000 Kreyol and French-speaking volunteers that I managed through social media, we translated and mapped over 80,000 messages in real-time. This was the first time that crowdsourcing has been used for humanitarian response in this manner. To date, it is still by far the largest. Summary Jeff is one of the co-founders of Kumu Networks - an NEA- and Khosla-backed startup spun out of Stanford University to commercialize research on Full Duplex Wireless Communications. Kumu Networks has invented a cancellation technology that allows a radio to transmit and receive on the same frequency at the same time. Full-duplex technology is widely applicable across many wireless standards (LTE, WiFi, Whitespaces, etc.), and it has many valuable use-cases without requiring any standards modifications. Jeff leads engineering for Kumu Networks. 
 
Jeff is currently on leave from the Ph.D. program at Stanford University, where he was working on full-duplex wireless and OpenRadio, which seeks to bring software-defined networking concepts to wireless RAN infrastructure. Before Stanford, Jeff co-founded OutSmart Power Systems, where he developed smart building networks to aid energy efficiency. He also worked as a design engineer with Sensata Technologies, developing low-cost, safety-critical automotive sensors. Summary Pradeep Singh, CEO of the Mohali Campus and Deputy Dean of the Indian School of Business. Responsible for operationalizing the four Institutes at ISB dedicated to Infrastructure, Manufacturing, Healthcare, and Public Policy.The Infrastructure and Manufacturing Institutes are being established in collaboration with Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), the Healthcare Institute in collaboration with the Wharton School, and the Public Policy Institute in partnership with the Fletcher School of International Diplomacy.He has over 35 years of work experience in government, non-government and private sector organizations, and in academia. 
Prior to joining ISB in 2013, He worked as Vice Chairman and Managing Director of IDFC Projects where he was dedicated to developing, financing, executing and managing infrastructure projects in India. Earlier, Mr. Singh was heading the Infrastructure Development Business of the IL&FS group, working in partnership with the private sector, more than ten state governments and with the Government of India for ten years. He worked, for seventeen years, as a member of the Indian Administrative Service in different leadership positions in state and central governments. He has been a visiting faculty member at Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University and has consulted for the Harvard Institute for International Development, World Bank, Asian Development Bank and the Government of Vietnam. He has been a member of the High Level Committee to review the implementation of ADB's Water Policy.Pradeep Singh holds an MPA from the Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University, and an MBA from the Punjab University, in India. Pradeep was also a Rotary International Graduate Fellow at Stanford University in Department of Engineering Economic Systems and holds a Masters and Bachelors degree in Nuclear Physics.

Summary Andrew Hsu (徐安廬，徐安庐) is a budding entrepreneur, neuroscientist, author, founder of a nonprofit for children, and technologist. 
 
He started at the University of Washington at age 12 and graduated with B.S. degrees in Neurobiology, Biochemistry, and Chemistry, and a minor in mathematics, at age 16.  
 
Before entering college, he was the youngest grand prize winner at the Washington State Science and Engineering Fair, and the youngest finalist in the history of the Intel International Science Fair, the top worldwide high school science competition. 
 
He is now a PhD candidate in the Neuroscience Graduate Program at Stanford University, where he was a Frances B. Nelson Fellow and a Smith Stanford Graduate Fellow. He is the author of several books, including A Life of Science. He was also a competitive swimmer when he was younger, posting the fastest 100 butterfly time on the West Coast of the US among 12-year-olds. 
 
Website: 
http://www.andrewhsu.com

- Writing books and articles Andrew Hsu (徐安廬，徐安庐) is a budding entrepreneur, neuroscientist, author, founder of a nonprofit for children, and technologist. 
 
He started at the University of Washington at age 12 and graduated with B.S. degrees in Neurobiology, Biochemistry, and Chemistry, and a minor in mathematics, at age 16.  
 
Before entering college, he was the youngest grand prize winner at the Washington State Science and Engineering Fair, and the youngest finalist in the history of the Intel International Science Fair, the top worldwide high school science competition. 
 
He is now a PhD candidate in the Neuroscience Graduate Program at Stanford University, where he was a Frances B. Nelson Fellow and a Smith Stanford Graduate Fellow. He is the author of several books, including A Life of Science. He was also a competitive swimmer when he was younger, posting the fastest 100 butterfly time on the West Coast of the US among 12-year-olds.

Experience Graduate Fellow Stanford University September 2012  – Present (3 years) The theme driving my current research is distinguishing the social psychological foundations of group-based and relation-based identities in groups and networks. 
 
I especially interested to know how social action through group and relational identities differs across cultures. I plan to conduct cross-cultural studies of group- and relation-motivated social action in Korea and China. Research Associate University of Washington August 2010  –  June 2011  (11 months) While at the University of Washington I theorized the differences between the internal and external legitimacy of the North Korean regime. I argue that North Korea, as well the other (post-)socialist Asian societies of China and Vietnam, claim legitimacy on the basis of promoting economic prosperity and maintaining ethno-political sovereignty. 
 
Through a meta-analysis of six surveys conducted with North Korean migrants in China and South Korea, I found evidence that while North Korean migrants believe their government is economically incompetent, they do not necessarily believe that it is politically illegitimate.
